Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Fundamentals of soft heat exchangers

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Highly stretchable heat exchangers could dramatically improve current thermoregulatory garments used in emergency and medical applications, such as firefighting, hazardous material cleanup, and medically required thermoregulation. These types of heat exchangers also would be the future basis for the thermal management of soft and wearable electronic technologies. In many such applications, active liquid cooling would be needed to dissipate combined heat from the electronics and the user's body. The fabrication of a stretchable, liquid cooled pad that could dissipate thermal loads only recently became possible due to the development of new classes of materials, such as hyperelastic liquid metal and elastomer composites. An added benefit of stretchable heat exchangers is that stretching the material could remove fouling deposits that deteriorate the performance of such devices in many industrial settings, which would provide a cost-effective, environmentally friendly alternative to currently utilized chemical and scrubbing cleaning methods. This research project aims to demonstrate a novel concept of soft heat exchangers that undergo shape change during operation and to develop a theoretical framework for prediction of their thermal performance. As part of this research project, semester-long "soft heat exchanger design challenge" class projects are being developed and assigned, which will increase the number of students involved in this research and accelerate the design and generation of soft, liquid cooled, wearable technologies.

Stretching will violate most assumptions used in design of conventional heat exchangers (e.g. constant areas and cross sections, heat transfer coefficients, and flow rates). Consequently, the design of soft heat exchangers requires development of new theoretical approaches for predicting their thermal performance. The primary hypothesis of this proposal is that quasi-static shape model can predict the thermal transport processes occurring within the device if its shape change occurs on a much longer time scale than the slowest heat transfer process (i.e., the device operates in the "gradual shape modulation regime"). Time scaling and the quasi-static shape models for single stream and concentric tube heat exchangers undergoing axial stretching and compression are being developed and tested experimentally. If the hypothesis is validated, then the quasi-static models can be used as a predictive tool to design devices operating in the gradual shape modulation regime. In case where the device operates in the "rapid shape modulation regime," in which time scales for the shape change are shorter or comparable to at least one heat transfer process, transient governing equations with moving boundary conditions are being solved. This research project serves as motivation for the development of theories for devices operating in this regime and provides preliminary experimental data for their validation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
By being soft, many natural systems are able to change shape to effectively move heat and control its transfer rate. For example, dependent on our cooling or heating need the capillaries in our skin dilate or constrict. Novel elastomer composites that remain soft despite addition of metal fillers (that remain liquid at room temperature) have opened up the possibility of creating deformable soft heat exchangers that are analogous to the natural ones. In this project we used these materials to develop single-stream, soft heat exchangers and explored their thermofluidic performance during periodic axial extension and retraction at varying frequencies. The transient device shape change invalidated many conventional assumptions employed in heat exchanger design making analysis of this device′s operation a non-trivial undertaking. 

The intellectual merit of this project was the development and experimental validation of a time scale analysis that quantifies when the conventional assumptions break down and highlight conditions under which the quasi-static shape assumption is applicable. In this ′gradual shape change regime′ the actuated device′s thermal behavior approaches that of stretched but static tubes whose performance can be predicted using standard approaches. We showed that this assumption was valid when the ratio of the representative times for heat conduction across the tube wall and the tube actuation was less than 0.001. Advancements in multimaterial 3D printing and soft conductive materials are likely to enable many novel soft thermal systems to emerge and potentially outperform their rigid analogues. The new theoretical framework introduced by this project will facilitate their development by providing a starting point for their thermal design.

The broader impacts of this project focused on applications of soft thermal composite heat exchangers to personal, high-power robotics, and wearable electronics thermal management. Specifically, the results of semester-long, application focused, soft heat exchanger design project in the PIs graduate heat transfer class accelerated generation of novel designs of liquid cooled garments. Despite the plethora of applications (from astronauts to multiple sclerosis patients), the current liquid cooled garments are made of hard plastic tubing that makes them cumbersome to use and excessively large. This work demonstrated that the use of soft, thermally conductive silicone-aluminum tubes can resolve these issues. To achieve optimal device performance, the material had to be designed to balance the increase in interfacial tube-substrate resistance due to composite stiffening and the decrease in bulk thermal resistance. As such, to enable the rational design of such tubes, a closed form thermomechanical model that predicts cooling performance as a function of material composition and geometry of the tube was developed and validated experimentally. The model was used to reveal optimal geometry and material compositions of the tube that minimize the required length of tubing and maximize the heat extracted from a metallic surface or skin. Using a holistic analysis, it was shown that besides significantly increasing overall cooling capability, the use of the optimized composite tubing can reduce the liquid-cooled garment size several times and enable novel operating modes.

 


Last Modified: 08/08/2020
Modified by: Konrad Rykaczewski
